row.header: What did you do this past week?
row.text: This past week, I finished a bunch of projects for my classes. I spent some time 2 days before career fair to prepare an elevator pitch. It was really helpful at the FoCS brunch and career fair. Nobody has ever told me to prepare an elevator pitch for career fairs like this. However, I've started recommending my friends to do this. I'll write more in detailed below. At career fair, I talked to about 10-15 companies. I mostly picked companies that have offices in Austin, since I want to stay here after graduation. Moreover, those local companies are the ones that I usually have more engaging conversations with. I skipped Amazon, Microsoft, Google and all other big Silicone Valley companies. Why? They will tell you to apply online, and the lines are very long, which take up your valuable time that you can use to talk to other cool smaller tech companies.
I have some Algorithm homework that I need to finish by Wednesday. It's starting to pick up pace very quickly. I hope I will not be overwhelmed by all the work during this semester

row.header: What will you do next week?
row.text: I have to apply for FT positions online for some of the companies that I talked to at the career fair. A lot of readings for algorithm and literature class need to be done, but I don't know how many I'll get to do.

row.header: What's my experience of the class?
row.text: Like last week, I think the class is a bit less structured than OOP (C++). I'm looking forward to the group projects though, because that's what I want to get out of the class. I think that the class will help me getting started with Python professionally.

Now, let's talk about elevator pitch. I recommend every single college student to make an elevator pitch that sells yourself to an employer. You start out with your name, then tell them about what you're interested in or something that you're passionate about. If you don't have a particular interest in any field, says that! Do not lie! Then, tell them about your experience and background. End the pitch with what you are looking for (internship, FT positions, etc.) Sometime, you might start with what you are looking for first, since they might not have that opportunity currently. So, you don't have to waste time talking to them and move on to the next company. Again, elevator pitch can be used in many different situations, so just make sure you streamline it to fit the purpose of the event.
